Issues.Title: has-navbar-fixed-* works only on html/body
Issues.Body:
This is about **Bulma**.

The class `has-navbar-fixed-top`/`has-navbar-fixed-bottom` can only be applied to the `<html>` or `<body>` element ([see docs](https://bulma.io/documentation/components/navbar/#fixed-navbar)). This restriction is unnecessarily strong. In my case, I'm using React, can't easily access the toplevel HTML tree and would like to trigger this definition conditionally in my app (somewhere deeper in tree). Unfortunately, Bulma doesn't provide that in this way.

### Overview of the problem

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
I'm using Bulma **version** 0.9.4
My **browser** is: Chromium
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**.

### Expected behavior

If the [definition in navbar.sass](https://github.com/jgthms/bulma/blob/master/sass/components/navbar.sass#L129-L134) would be a bit more extensive, meaning the restriction with `<html>` or `<body` would be removed, I could use the Bulma class as intended.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "has-navbar-fixed-* works only on html/body" (#3583)

Issues.Title: Add an equivalent of Bootstrap's stretched links
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
It's a **feature request**.
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
I'm using Bulma **version** [0.9.4]
My **browser** is: Firefox 104.0.1
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**

### Description

Currently, there's no class in Bulma that is a functional equivalent of [Bootstrap's stretched links](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/5.2/helpers/stretched-link/). In short, it's a class that, when applied to the `<a>` element, makes the entire containing block, such as cards, clickable as if it were part of the link. This not only improves code readability, but also makes the performed action more clear since it also highlights the `.stretched-link` element.

Currently, the closest alternative is to make the box an `<a>` element. While it does the job, it highlights the entire box, and putting any links inside it, like a button, breaks the whole thing.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Add an equivalent of Bootstrap's stretched links" (#3574)

Issues.Title: Media Query can fail on scaled displays
Issues.Body:
<!-- PLEASE READ THE FOLLOWING INSTRUCTIONS -->

<!-- Choose one of the following: -->
This is about **Bulma**.

<!-- Is it about Bulma or about the Docs? -->
<!-- Is it a bug/feature/question or do you need help? -->
<!-- If it's a bug, is it a browser bug? -->

### Overview of the problem

<!-- UNCOMMENT THE APPROPRIATE LINES -->

This is about the Bulma **CSS framework**
<!-- This is about the Bulma **Docs** -->
<!-- I'm using Bulma **version** [x.x.x] -->
<!-- My **browser** is: -->
<!-- This is a **Sass** issue: I'm using version [x.x.x] -->
<!-- I am sure this issue is **not a duplicate**? -->

### Description

<!-- Description of the bug, enhancement, or question -->
I found on a machine of mine that uses 125% display scaling with a 2560 x 1440 resolution if I snap a browser to 50% of the screen it ends up in a partial pixel width that is right between some of the `@media` queries. Even though you would think that with a calculation of 2560 / 1.25 * 0.50 = 1024 everything would be ok, the browser actually reports a width of 1023.20 pixels. 

Now this means that neither queries with `max-width: 1023px;` nor queries with `min-width: 1024px;` will take effect.

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set display resolution to 2560 x 1440
2. Set display scale to 125%
3. Snap a browser window to either half of the screen
4. Try to open the nav menu on a site using the bulma CSS framework

### Expected behavior

<!-- What you expected to happen -->
The menu in tablet mode should open when I click the "hamburger" icon.

### Actual behavior

<!-- What actually happened -->
I noticed that when I tried to open the menu nothing happened. This is because the media query applies `display: block;` to items with `.navbar-menu.is-active`; however, none of the queries match due to partial pixels.

I am sure there are plenty more small issues that would occur due to this.

### Possible fix

I took some time and found that in **mixins.sass** I can replace lines such as `@media screen and (max-width: $device - 1px)` with `@media screen and (max-width: $device - 0.001px)`. The sass compiler does not seem to have any issue handling partial pixel values and browsers are ok with them as well.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Media Query can fail on scaled displays" (#3572)

Issues.Title: Discussion on name
Issues.Body:
The name Bulma is problematic, because it looks too much at a glance like "Bulimia", which is a very sensitive issue for some people.

I suggest picking something more neutral...
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Discussion on name" (#3557)

Issues.Title: Fixes #336, is-gapless unable to be used in conjunction with is-offset-X
Issues.Body:
This is a **bugfix**.
Using gapless columns and offset at the same time, cancels the offset.  Issue #336 

### Proposed solution
Removing margin: 0 from columns.scss fixes the problem. This was suggested on the issue, but does not seem to have been added yet. I have tested this fix and it is not causing any issues with the grid.

### Tradeoffs
None

###Testing done
Tested on latest Chrome desktop (Mac) and iOS Chrome.

###Changelog updated?
No
